questions.question: "Should i add fuel stabilizer to the fresh gas before putting it in the mower tank?"
questions.author: Mo

answers.author: Response from Husqvarna
answers.text: Hi Mo. No, per your user manual, you should use fresh, clean, regular unleaded gasoline with a minimum of 87 octane only. Do not mix oil with gasoline. Purchase fuel in quantities that can be used within 30 days to assure fuel freshness. You only need to add fuel stabilizer when mower will be stored for a long period of time, especially for winter storage. But it's recommended that you empty fuel from your mower before storing, so you wouldn't need stabilizer at all unless you choose NOT to empty the tank. Gasoline that sits in your mower's fuel tank for months and months degrades, gets stale, and even thickens, eventually clogging the carburetor and fuel lines in the system. It also attracts moisture, which can lead to corrosion. It's best to empty all fuel prior to storing your mower for winter. Should you choose NOT to empty the fuel prior to storing your mower, it's a good idea to add a fuel stabilizer to the tank, and run the engine for at least 10 minutes to give the stabilizer a chance to flow through the entire fuel system. Fuel stabilizer is an acceptable alternative to avoid tacky deposits during storage. Always follow the mix ratio found on stabilizer container. Do not empty the gas tank and carburetor if using fuel stabilizer. Thank you so much for considering Husqvarna for your outdoor power equipment needs.

answers.author: HisDudeness
answers.text: Fuel Stabilizer is not necessary as long as the gas is fresh and you plan on using the mower regularly. I would use fuel stabilizer prior to storing the mower for the Winter.

questions.question: "What is the difference between front, rear and all wheel drive? And can anyone recommend one over the other?"
questions.author: Ray

answers.author: HisDudeness
answers.text: The self propel drive drives the front wheels on a front wheel drive, the rear wheels on a rear wheel drive and all four wheels on an all wheel drive. Between the front and rear wheel drive, I prefer the rear wheel drive. It gets better traction. My All-Wheel drive seems more powerful than a front or rear wheel drive. An all wheel drive would probably be better on a steeper slope.

answers.author: Response from Husqvarna
answers.text: Good question Ray. In some ways, it's about preference, but your yard type can help you determine which drive system is ideal. Most self-propelled walk-behind lawn mowers are front-wheel-drive (FWD), and are best for level terrain or yards with small slopes. Also, since the drive wheels are in front, it's easy to tip the mower up so you can turn it easier than with other drive systems – especially when you get to the end of your mowing path and need to turn the other way. Rear-wheel-drive (RWD) provides more traction at the center of the mower, helping you mow hilly terrain easily. And finally, all-wheel-drive (AWD) models provide power to all four wheels, making them best for hilly terrain, uneven terrain, and tougher mowing conditions. All of these drive systems are combined with self-propelling, and together, make the mower do the hard work for you -- especially versus a mower you have to actually push! Hope that helps with your decision. For what it's worth, I have one of all-wheel-drive Husqvarna models and LOVE it! Well, I should say my 14-year-old son loves it since he does the mowing! Thank you so much for considering Husqvarna for your outdoor power equipment needs.

questions.question: "How come the engine doesn't stay on when I let go of the presence control bar. After holding down the presence control bar to start the engine the bl"
questions.author: Slee

answers.author: Response from Husqvarna
answers.text: Hi Slee. A lawn mower is a dangerous tool if used carelessly or incorrectly, and can cause serious, even fatal, injuries. The blade turns when the engine is running. Federal regulations require an engine control to be installed on lawn mowers in order to minimize the risk of blade contact injury. With that said, all walk-behind lawn mowers are made to shut down when you release the engine brake handle. The engine brake is designed to stop the engine. When the grip on the engine brake handle is released, the engine should stop and the drive should disengage, and blades stop turning. You should not, under any circumstances, attempt to defeat the function of the operator control. Thank you so much for choosing Husqvarna for your outdoor power equipment needs.

questions.question: "what type of gas should be used? Also, what cylinder is the engine?"
questions.author: Terry

answers.author: Response from Husqvarna
answers.text: Hi Terry. Husqvarna lawn mowers have 4-cycle or 4-stroke engines, and use fresh, clean, regular unleaded gasoline with a minimum of 87 octane only. Do not mix oil with gasoline. Purchase fuel in quantities that can be used within 30 days to assure fuel freshness. Alcohol-blended fuels (called gasohol or using ethanol or methanol) can attract moisture which leads to separation and formation of acids during storage. Acidic gas can damage the fuel system of an engine while in storage. Thank you so much for considering Husqvarna for your outdoor power equipment needs.

answers.author: Response from Husqvarna
answers.text: Daniel - The front wheels can "lock" up sometimes when pulling the unit backwards depending on how the unit is being operated. To avoid the wheels from locking up, the operator should allow the unit to roll forward a couple inches after letting go of the drive control. This allows the front transmission to disengage and then it will free roll in both directions.

questions.question: "If we had a fungus on the lawn then cut it, what can I clean the blades with before cutting again beside the garden hose wash?"
questions.author: Steve

answers.author: Response from Husqvarna
answers.text: Hi Steve. First, use a steel brush to remove debris and rust. If necessary, use warm, soapy water to clean stubborn debris (i.e., the fungus). Although it may sound a bit strange, some people use cooking spray or oil to help clean grass off mower blades. While you're at it, it's a good time to have your blades sharpened. Keeping your lawn mower blades clean and sharp is just as important as engine maintenance when it comes to ensuring equipment performance and longevity. Dull mower blades can unevenly rip or shred grass, leaving it torn, dry, and susceptible to disease. Replacing or sharpening the blade(s) on your mower blade will ensure a healthy lawn. Remember, blades are sharp, and can cause serious injury! Please, please make sure you follow the instructions in your user manual for removing blades or attempting any cleaning or maintenance. Thank you so much for choosing Husqvarna for your outdoor power equipment needs.
